subject: Re: [junit] Message texts
msgSnippet: ... Personally I prefer using the message string to document the assertion rather than defining the error message upon failure. To me doing so seems logical
messageBody:
--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
> David Plass wrote:
>
> > So you'd write
> > assertTrue("someBoolean is not true!",
> someBoolean);
> >
> > Or as another example
> > assertEquals("The answer isn't the same!",
> expected, actual);
>
> Yes, but /very/ context-sensitive. I often write
> failure text as
> incredulous statements.
>
> assertNotNull("Joe has no name?!", joe.getName());
> --
> J. B. Rainsberger,
> Diaspar Software Services
> http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
> Let's write software that people understand
>

Personally I prefer using the message string to
document the assertion rather than defining the
error message upon failure. To me doing so seems
logical because JUnit reports assertion failures.

So instead of the style proposed above I'd prefer:

assertTrue("someBoolean is true", someBoolean);

assertEquals("The answer is right",
expected,
actual);

assertNotNull("Joe has a name", joe.getName());

The reason why I prefer using this style is because
I find assertions like the one below confusing to read

assertTrue("someBoolean is not true!", someBoolean);

In a team environment I believe it's important that
the team chooses between either of these styles and
uses it consistently.

Kind regards,
Sven
